Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling returns home from school visibly upset after a difficult day with friends.
Situation2: A holiday travel surge fills the approach fixes with moderate holding delays.
Story: I was just settling into my shift at the control tower, eyes flicking between radar screens, when my phone buzzed. It was a text from my stepbrother, “Can you talk? Had a rough day.” I pictured him trudging home, shoulders slumped, the way he gets when his friends shut him out. I knew he needed me—Mom always said we had to look out for each other, especially after the families merged. But right now, the airspace was a mess. Holiday flights stacked up in holding patterns, pilots radioing in, my supervisor’s voice sharp in my headset: “We can’t afford mistakes today.” My hands hovered over the console, mind split. My stepbrother expected me to be there, to listen, to help him through the mess in his world. But dozens of planes depended on my focus, and one slip could mean chaos. My heart pounded as I stared at the blinking screens, torn between the family I promised to support and the lives I was responsible for in the sky.
